title: Mariners pick Servais as their new manager
text: Mariners pick Servais as their new manager SHARE: advertisement | your ad here Seattle Mariners on Friday announced the hiring of Scott Servais as their manager. Servais will be formally introduced in a press conference Monday, the team said. Through the course of the 20-plus years Ive known Scott, Ive come to see him as one of the most complete, well balanced and inclusive baseball people in the industry, Mariners general manager Jerry Dipoto said in press release. Ive been fortunate enough to call him a teammate as a player, while also having worked closely with him as an organizational leader in both Colorado and Los Angeles. He is a communicator with strong baseball acumen and leadership skills. I truly believe his strong character and career experiences as a player, coach and executive have prepared him for this opportunity. Servais, 48, spent the past four seasons as an assistant general manager with the Los Angeles Angels. In that role, he worked closely with Dipoto on all aspects of baseball operations, with a focus on player development. I am excited and grateful for the opportunity to manage the Seattle Mariners, Servais said in the release. It has long been my goal to manage a big league team and while I took a slightly different path than many, I am confident in my ability to lead. We have a terrific core of players and Im looking forward to bringing in a coaching staff that will help me establish a winning culture here as we work toward putting a championship-caliber team on the field for the fans of the Northwest.Servais is the 17th full-time skipper in Mariners history.Prior to joining the Angels, Scott spent six seasons (2006-2011) as the Texas Rangers senior director of player development. With the Rangers he was responsible for the on-field development of all players in the Rangers minor-league system. He also was responsible for instructing Texas major-league catchers.Servais spent one season (2005) as a professional scout for the Rockies, after spending the prior two years as a roving catching instructor for the Chicago Cubs (2003-04).Servais had an 11-year major-league playing career with the Houston Astros (1991-95, 2001), Chicago Cubs (1995-98), San Francisco Giants (1999-2000) and Colorado Rockies (2000). He batted .245 with 30 doubles, 63 home runs and 319 RBI in 820 career games.
